info.game_comments:
Mark Brown game 4.
(Sofia: Hey Jimmy, William Howard Taft lived here.)
(Jimmy: Let's go inside and check out how big the bathtub is!)

(1, 1).clue: A huge monolith featuring 121 carved figures adorns Vigeland Sculpture Park in this Norwegian capital

(2, 1).clue: Mallory Tarcher has had a hand in continuing Lamb Chop, created by this woman, her mother

(3, 1).clue: February 29 baby Karl von Baer established that babies develop from these female reproductive cells

(5, 1).clue: Performed to make you part of the Mormon Church, it needs a body of water large enough for total immersion

(6, 1).clue: After being made with a new metal in 1883, the U.S. coin known as the half dime became known as this

(1, 2).clue: Sir Francis Chantrey's statue of King George IV stands in a corner of this famous London square

(2, 2).clue: Known as the Foster Imposters, a puppet pair of these animals want to be Foster Farms products

(3, 2).clue: Morarji Desai, former prime minister of this country, died in 1995 aged 99 (or just 24)

(4, 2).clue: Iron while is the strike hot
(4, 2).correct response: Strike while the iron is hot

(5, 2).clue: They're the first 2 words in the Book of Common Prayer (1549 ed.) wedding service

(6, 2).clue: Nickname of Melissa Gilbert's character on "Little House on the Prairie"

(1, 3).clue: Devon House, built in 1881 by one of the Caribbean's 1st black millionaires, is a major attraction in this Jamaican capital

(2, 3).clue: In 1989 NBC had this alien help host the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade

(3, 3).clue: This Italian celebrated his 6th birthday in 1816, days after his opera "The Barber of Seville" premiered

(5, 3).clue: As used during the Last Supper they're the food & drink blessed during the eucharist

(6, 3).clue: According to Tennyson, the Light Brigade moved into the Valley of Death by these increments

(1, 4).clue: Te Papa Tongarewa, Maori for "repository of things precious", is the name of the waterfront museum in this city

(2, 4).clue: Humans on this 2002 Fox puppet series include Sarah Silverman & Seth Green

(3, 4).clue: This actor & jeans model seen here really is in the "junior league"; he's only had 7 birthdays

(4, 4).clue: Better one are heads than two
(4, 4).correct response: Two heads are better than one

(5, 4).clue: Kol Nidre, which negates vows made between humans & God, is recited on the eve of this Jewish holiday

(6, 4).clue: A "half" this is a dive that includes a half backward somersault & ends facing the board

(1, 5).clue: A hill known as El Panecillo -- "The Bread Roll" -- provides fine views of this Ecuadorian city

(2, 5).clue: On "Unhappily Ever After", he supplied the voice of Mr. Floppy

(3, 5).clue: In 1896 Herman Hollerith, born on Leap Day 1860, organized the Tabulating Machine Co., which evolved into this giant

(4, 5).clue: Pen mightier is than the the sword
(4, 5).correct response: The pen is mightier than the sword

(5, 5).clue: This kind of mass has included a "Dies Irae"; Mozart wrote one late in his life

(6, 5).clue: For thorium-234 it's about 25 days; for thorium-232, about 14 billion years

(1, 1).clue: Taft was criticized for not doing more to reduce the power of Joe Cannon, holder of this post in Congress

(2, 1).clue: A steenbok is a grassland antelope; this is the man who wrote "Tortilla Flat"

(4, 1).clue: This Motown group's many '60s hits include "Stop! In the Name of Love"

(5, 1).clue: In the Hawaiian language, kane is a man & this is a woman

(6, 1).clue: In 1998 this largest automaker of South Korea acquired a major stake in Kia Motors

(1, 2).clue: With Taft & Teddy Roosevelt splitting the Republican vote, this Democrat easily won the 1912 election

(2, 2).clue: Elder is a species of tree; eider is a species of this

(4, 2).clue: Giant of the '70s airwaves seen here

(5, 2).clue: In the 1790s, cattle were brought to Hawaii by George Vancouver who served under this discoverer of the islands

(6, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew demonstrates)  It's the method I'm using to type a memo...I was never very good

(1, 3).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports from Cincinnati)  Before ascending to the presidency, the only job Taft was voted into was as one of these in Ohio

(2, 3).clue: Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne infection; this was the '80s TV show hosted by Deney Terrio

(4, 3).clue: A bestselling album of 1945 was from this bandleader who'd died the previous year

(5, 3).clue: Known as the "Napoleon of the Pacific", he united the islands by 1810 & forged them into a kingdom

(6, 3).clue: It's another name for a filbert

(1, 4).clue: Taft set up this bureau in the Interior Dept. to reduce underground explosions, that sort of thing

(2, 4).clue: Baskin-Robbins creates fancy ice cream treats; he created the ballet "Fancy Free"

(4, 4).clue: "Shake It" is the last song on his 1983 album "Let's Dance"

(5, 4).clue: This island's Kalaupapa National Historical Park preserves the Kalaupapa leper settlement

(6, 4).clue: Despite a clubfoot, Lord Byron played cricket for this London school in its rivalry match against Eton

(1, 5).clue: Alliterative term for Taft's foreign policy, which emphasized monetary investment

(2, 5).clue: Topaz is a yellow stone; this is the U.S. national park with the highest waterfall

(4, 5).clue: In 1959 she had a hit with the following[What A Difference A Day Makes]

(5, 5).clue: Volcanic craters on Oahu include Diamond Head, Koko Head & this "bowl" in the heart of Honolulu

(6, 5).clue: Largely through the efforts of Clive Cussler, this Confederate sub that sank with its crew in 1864 has been recovered

(0, 0).clue: This venture was financed by the sale of souvenir stamps & medals & a large donation from businessman Georgios Averoff
